subnotes.content: Colo. Jewish Fam. Alb., 1859-1992: p. 69 (first generation: Israel and Rebecca Kortz; second generation: Morris and Rachel Levitsky Kortz; third generation: Jess and Rose Dachmann Kortz; fourth generation Pearle Rae and Seymour Feldman; fifth generation: Alan Dean and Lisa Laff, Kenneth Martin Laff and Marian Keane; sixth generation: LLaura Susan Laff, James Austin Laff)
Includes Nathan (Nat) Berry, 1898-1954, his children by Dorothy (Dokes) Kobey Berry, 1905-2009, and their descendants.

Hirschfeld Family Papers includes materials from and about the following members of the Hirschfeld family: A. B. (Abraham Bernard) Hirschfeld (1888- 1957), his son Edward Hirschfeld (1907-1984 ), his grandson A. Barry Hirschfeld, and A. Barry Hirschfeld's wife Arlene (nee Friedman) Hirschfeld). A. B. Hirschfeld founded A. B. Hirschfeld Press, which was later operated by Edward Hirschfeld. The company is now called National Hirschfeld and operated by A. Barry Hirschfeld.

Use for persons retaining the Russian form of name; or using the Anglicized forms: Spivakovsky, Spivakov, and Spivakoff; the German form: Spivakowsky; or the the shortened forms used by some immmigrants to the United States:  Spivack, Spivacke, Spivak, etc.

(Gift of Mrs. Ben Bockla (Nina Sosne, daughter of ? Sosne), 2783 W. 14th Ave., Sosne Family, Gert Sigman (16), Anna Cohan (13), Lottie Craig (10), Mrs. Abramson - Rachel Sosne mother (45), Sara Stein (19) Margaret Sosne, niece, circa 1913.); archivist's description (Formal portrait of Rachel Sosne (Mrs. Abraham Sosne) and her daughters Gert Sosne Sigman, Anna Sosne Cohan, Lottie Sosne Craig and Sara Sosne Stein. Members of the Sosne family ran the Capitol Wet Wash Laundry on West Colfax Avenue in Denver, Colorado.)
The Cohen family were one of the first settlers of the town of Aspen, Colorado. Elias Cohen moved there by 1891 and managed David Hyman's mining properties.

Members of the family in the Denver area include:   Morris and Zelda Averch, Anna Averch Kaminsky,Stanley Averch, Dave and Verner Averch, Evelyn Averch, Eva Averch, Meyer Averch and Estelle Averch (Stine).

Includes:  George (Gedalia) Toltz, Minnie (Munya) Toltz and their children Ida Toltz Radetsky, Israel Toltz, and Rose toltz Mizel. The family became active members of the west-side East European Jewish community in Denver.
As of , included:  Harry and Rose Battock and four of their children; Ben, Sophie, Joe and Mary.
As of the 1920s included:  Jacob and Charlotte Gordon, their daughters, Bess, Baila, Eleanor and a son.

Denver Goldblatt families: Samuel and Pearl Goldblatt; children Helen, Goldie, Jenny, Bill, Morris, Leo, Milt, and Mike. William and Helen Goldblatt; children Ruth and Marvin.  As of 1914, included William and Helen Goldblatt, and their children, Ruth and Marvin Goldblatt residing on Newton St. in Denver.
Lived in Virginia City, Nevada.
Branches of the family in Colorado include:
Trinidad, Colorado Moses family included Harry and Rosa and their children Albert and Ethel

Herman and Nettie Weinberger immigrated from Hungary.  Their twelve children were Simon Weinberger, Rose Berkowitz, Pauline Schwartz, Maurice Weinberger, Henry Weinberger, Jacob Weinberger, Fannie Rosenblum, Jennie Levy, Ethel Mann, Joseph Weinberger, Lulu Klein, and Arnold Weinberger.  Jacob Weinberger married Blanche Solomon and had children Adrienne Weinberger and Richard C. Weinberger.
Use for:  Cline family, Kleine family, Kline family
Photographer, Suzanne Shelton Buckley Papers
photographer, dance photos

Includes Herbert Alonzo Howe and his wife, Fannie Shattuck Howe; their children Julian Osgood, Hubert Shattuck, Warren Francis and Ernest J. Howe, and their grandchildren, including Julian's son Herbert Julian Howe. Most are DU alumni.
Includes Joseph C. (Joseph Cummings) Shattuck, his wife Harriet Mason Shattuck, their children Fannie McClurg Shattuck Howe and Orville Shattuck.
Includes Nelson and his father Famuel.  Family came from Lithuania, was part of the West Colfax Jewish community in Denver, and has connections in Cincinnatti, Ohio.
Morris S. and Anna Ginsberg Hayutin family

As of 1902, includes sisters Millie (Mrs. Joseph Levy), Jennie (Mrs. Joseph Washer), Rose (Mrs. David Greinetz), Mary (Mrs. M. Joseph Gottstein), Birdie (Mrs. M. Schraiberg), and Leah (Mrs. Harris Kobey, mother of Dorothy “Dokes” Kobey Berry), and a brother Joe Sheffel.  Also includes their parents Isaac, 1842-1893 and Rebecca, 1845-1886.

The Kobey family of Aspen and Denver, Colo. includes: Dorothy Kobey Berry, six siblings, their parents Leah Sheffel and Harris Kobey, their uncle Ben Kobey, her husband Nathan Berry, and their three children, Harold, Joan, and Susan.
